reviewText:
I am going to give this game a positive review. It has pretty good music, nice game play, not too buggy, and overall deserves to be noted.

That being said...

The obnoxiously pretentious stench of unwashed hipster brogrammer self-proclaimed-artist/entrepreneur will probably make you want to vomit the third time the game asks you to tweet your progress to your friends.

The moon phases gimmick is also really bad. Someone deserves to have a couple of fingers cut off for this.

In the end, I get the feeling that ten years from now, the people who's name are on the credits for this title are going to have something both to be proud of, and something to regret.

Go read the negative reviews and count the use of the word “pretentious”. They are on to something.

This game is a MASTER PIECE that IS NOT FOR EVERY PLAYER.
This game is neither a point and click adventure nor a rogue-like nor RPG.
It is most a GENRE BY ITSELF, a masterpiece as I have said.

Graphics and music are georgous, but its own style goes from the menuscreen to the interface of the game, even to its internal logic, which is not designed to be fully understood. This is not a game for a harcore gameplay, you are supposed to guess what to do next by observing with your five senses inside the game, and out of the game too, because the time at you play it influences in the developing of the game. You are understanding the game, its logic and its own rythm as you play it, so judging it just at the begining is not to judge the game, but reject its potential.

reviewText: Sword & Sworcery is a short adventure game. It introduces a minimalistic and novel way to bring adventure games to touchscreen devices, but left me with the feeling that a pc game can be so much more. In adventures I live for atmosphere. While Sword & Sworcery's art and music do that perfectly (I really recommend the soundtrack), the narrative harshly drops the built up immersion in favor of ironically juxtaposing prose with blasé pop chatter. After finishing the game, I still don't have an understanding of my character's motives beyond that of any Mario game, and found no memorable companions along the way.

reviewText:
Sword & Sworcery features a female warrior on a quest to reunite triangles lost in a mysterious fantasy realm located somewhere between dream and reality. The intriguing story is divided into three increasingly long sessions, each briefly presented by monologue from The Archetype, with a shorter final one acting as a sort of conclusion.

Very appealing and well executed pixel art embodies artistic simplicity met with astounding precision and remarkable sensitivity. Simple but fluid animations infused into every corner of the world, along with subtle color shifts that gracefully enhance the liveliness of the scenes, create a mesmerizing environment unlike any other.

A solid soundtrack suits the mood perfectly, composed mostly of rock-tinged retro ambient ballads, properly extravagant mood trips, doom and gloom, and a wealth of high quality atmospheric sounds.

Dishearteningly and despite all the game does exceptionally well, there is too much to loathe about everything done wrong, or too peculiar to be enjoyable. Every time it surprised me with an awesome moment, of which there are a good few, it had to immediately remind me of its many glaringly frustrating elements.

Sword & Sworcery's totally awkward controls, obviously initially created for touch devices, do not play well in a mouse configuration, despite efforts made to ease the transition. Almost every design decision taken by the developer seems counter intuitive or ergonomically inefficient. Thankfully simple hints pop up from time to time to explain the more cryptic expectations.

Dreadful combat sequences require learning unavoidable patterns and hitting one of two buttons at the right moment, often with no clear consequence until repeated exposure. Later combat sequences can only be described as cheap rhythm games akin to playing ping pong. And waiting. Battles are exceptionally long for surprisingly so little action, as most of the time is spent waiting for a cue. Fights are so unequivocally counter-intuitive that an explanation comes after each failed attempt in the game's Megatome, a sort of encyclopedia chronicling important characters' personal thoughts.

The same boring and uneventful fights keep re-happening fairly frequently, without actual rewards, presumably to artificially extend playing time.

There are some funny and/or clever bits of dialogues and descriptions, though it eventually becomes banal to read blurbs drenched in juvenile hipster crass hidden among rare gems. Despite the intriguing setting and the very charming characters, the whole affair reads like an aspiring author's collection of best attempts at mystic alliterations and esoteric one-liners.

Most Sworcery puzzles mainly consist in (optionally) ingesting magic mushrooms to see specific parts of the environment lit up, then figuring out in which pre-determined order the game expects you to click to release sylvan sprites. I found no logic to these segments most of the time, so it turned out to be tedious guesswork for the more obtuse ones and deceivingly simple otherwise.

Parts of the game accurately synchronize with the actual moon's phases, marking one of the game's most unique and truly original ideas. Fortunately, the developers realized that being able to play entire sections of their game only once a month at full and new moons was a spectacularly bad proposition, and they built a way to temporarily alter the phases of the moon directly in the game, essentially circumventing the entire feature's purpose and value.

A few other minor flaws and annoyances include the main character constantly referring to herself in the second person, completely useless Twitter integration on every single line, slow character movement, and too often self-referential for its own benefit.

This game offers a beautiful world in which I would love to get lost for hours, if only it offered anything worthwhile to do. As it stands, its long list of frustrating elements far outweigh everything else I so desperately loved.

reviewText:
Perhaps I'm not the best to judge this game considering I have 2 hours logged in it. But that's the thing; In the two hours I've been playing the game, nothing has happened! I'll concede that the art is good, and the music is fantastic, but if I wanted to sit there and listen to music, I'd be doing that instead of trying to play a game.

The game tries to be atmospheric, but all this does is set a pace that's way too slow. After a while, I hadn't really DONE anything. I had gone where the little arrows told me to go, and done what the little text boxes told me to do, but that's about it. I want to like this game, and I want to see the poetry in it, but no poem I've ever read requires me to sit through two hours of holding down a mouse and watching a pixellated character walk across a screen just to get to the good bit, wherever it may be.

If you're into atmosphere, or you want to stare at pretty pixels while relaxing background music plays, buy this game. If you want to play a videogame, don't.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I love the rest of capy's games, but this one I couldn't get into. The art style and music is great. It is in the gameplay where this game falls short. Very easy and uninspired gameplay. It feels like a stripped down version of rpg combat. The game has you progress by walking SLOWLY between areas solving the same tedious puzzles over and over again, just to obtain these 3 triangles called trigon pieces. The overall game was not very fun, from slow walk speed, to tedious puzzles, a predictable story, to banal combat. The moment when I stopped was after obtaining the 2nd trigon piece and having the game say that in order to obtain the last piece I had to wait real world days for the next full moon. You could always change your clock but that would prevent you from getting 100%. Overall a beautiful looking yet disappointing game that is more fun to look at than to play.

reviewText:
Sometimes it pays to be pretty. Especially if your personality is akin to that of a differently-abled llama.

The pixel art is great, no doubt. However the scenery soon becomes repetitive and the initial charm of the landscapes diminishes.
The clunky, unintuitive contols frustrate often. In particular, a chase scene quickly goes from tense and urgent to mouse-throwingly-irritating. As you try to escape, your mouse clicks grab" the screen
date: dragging the scene in the opposite direction of the one in which you were attempting to move. Throw in the painfully glacial pace of your protagonist and navigating this lovely low-res world becomes a chore. Essentially the gameplay itself is pinned upon almost a singular mechanic
recommended: initiating "scorcery mode" and activating the environmental surroundings through mouse clicks in a specific order to release Forest Sprites. It's simplistic at its core
hoursPlayed: but often obtuse. You may however consume mushrooms to highlight these specific points of interaction
voteText: but maybe 'shrooms is how we've ended up here in the first place.\n\nFor all the emphasis on the soundtrack or the "EP"
helpfulPercent: the tunes here are generally uninspiring
votesHelpful: background ambience. A grating bell-dong accompanies every scroll of on-screen text that feels quite unnecessary. Although
votesTotal: the grunts and cries of your protaganist during battle sound fierce and have a Link-like charm. There's also a rambling
votesFunny: awkward monologue from a character that was somewhat amusing.\n\nThe attempted casual
commentsCount: modern style of the text is an innovative idea

I found the choice of a female lead character to be a commendable one. It's just a shame she doesn't have more to do.

Super disappointing."

reviewText: I have to say, I do like to play the 'experimental' games as they are usually interesting concepts and make a change from the usual run of the mill FPS I usualy play. Having said that, I didn't especially enjoy this. It's decent enough, and certainly intriguing. I personally just found the control system somewhat cumbersome, and had a really hard time figuring ut what the heck i was meant to be doing most of the time. I don't mind games that leave you to figure stuff out on your own, but most of the time, I just ended up wandering about doing random things until something happened to progress, more by good luck than logically figured out.\nHaving said that, the good soundtrack and retro style graphics did apeal and kind of added to the otherworldly-ness (not sure if that's a word!) of the atmosphere. There wasn't anything particularly terrible about this game, but nothing particularly stood out about this, aside from the soundtrack. And, I confess, the link into the social media kind of felt more gimmicky than innovative.  would I recommend it? In all honesty, probably not. There are plenty of 'experimental' games out there which feel much more accessible than this, and manage to combine innnovative ideas and gameplay (Dear Esther, for example, or Shelter even are two that spring to mind). Full marks for effort, but a bit too inaccessible for me.

reviewText:
Wait, let me explain.

SB:S&S EP should not be considered a video game in the traditional sense.  It is an interactive multimedia art experience.  Coming into it with that attitude will provide the right frame of mind to potentially enjoy it.  All art is subjective.

As a game it isn't very interesting.  The world to be explored is composed of a handful of set scenes.  Combat is both simple and repetitive.  Most of the puzzles are simple if you are keeping up with the dialog.  You will not be challenged here.

There is a very strong 'hipster' vibe throughout.  If that's what you are into, huzzah, but for me it was grating.

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP was an interesting game. ...But not interesting enough.

And what I mean by that is through my complete playthrough of the game, the game felt like it was trying to convey a bigger thought. A bigger picture and a larger frame of imagination.
What bothers me is the game conveys these thoughts but then suddenly ends when it felt like it needed to start show casing it's cloud of information and thoughts of enlightenment.

It was a pretty impressionable lacking feeling.

The world SB:S&S takes place in was one that felt like it had a substantial amount of lore and background, but you were just a watcher who commands a Scythian to complete a quest they called A Woeful Errand" It felt like that besides the errand
date:
the world it takes place in isn't extremely meaningful to you as you're there to guide the Scythian to complete her mission. So most lore can easily be ignored or you can make the Scythian get a little bit of background information from reading her thoughts on the world around her and talking to other people. I appreciate that is was natural and people weren't just flushing the worlds background out of them into you.

The game has an interesting way of connecting you to the characters involved in the game. Your character shortly after starting her errand aquires a book dubbed "The Megatome"
The Megatome allows you to see how many days until the next real life black moon or full moon. It also allows you to read the minds of others and establishes an interesting connection to people around you. Mind you
recommended: this function isn't gimmicky and isn't overdone. It's pretty simple but interesting.\n\nThis game is a point and click adventure without a doubt. It was released first on the IOS and then for PC. During my playthrough
hoursPlayed: i'd say it's a little better suited for the IOS. But it works pretty darn well on the PC too
voteText: so it is a pretty good port nonetheless.\nThe playing world is pretty narrow in-movement
helpfulPercent: but as far as what you need to do and exploring goes. The game respects your thoughts on where to go and what you should do. There is times where I got lost or tried to solve a puzzle in a area where there was no puzzle to be solved (by using the song of sworcery). But ultimately after maybe ten minutes at worst
votesHelpful: i'd figure out where I needed to be and then they game kept moving.\nI appreciate that and the time loss isn't that bad
votesTotal: the only thing that will probably bother you about that is when you gotta hike all the way to where you need to be. The Scythians pacing can be a bit tiresome and annoying sometimes.\n\nThe art style of the game is pretty great. Sometimes I feel like it wasn't tied too strongly to the story
votesFunny:
so sometimes the art styles impact fell kind of short when the story was uprising towards it approach to its climax.
Though at-times the art and the colors and sounds mixed-in with what was happening helped achieve a state of artistic enlightenment and a different kind of view on things. ...Also getting high on the occassional in-game mushroom helped that out a bit sometimes.

Unfortunately
commentsCount: the same can be equally be said about the music. The music was perfect in areas and it carried emotions out of me. Feelings of intensity

reviewText:
S:S&S is a game that tries too hard.

Its visual and audio style are both incredible, and the game is a joy to experience, but it quickly goes downhill once you start trying to actually do something.

The controls are the first thing that hits you. It becomes immediately apparent that this is an iPad game. 'Replacing touch with a mouse is clumy, but I can deal with that,' you say. And so you deal with it. The controls don't seem to get more intuitive, but at least they're workable.

Then you get to a girl named Girl, and that seems quirky. And this quirkiness stays pretty consistent, which means it gets a little annoying. There's a g-man that says a bunch of big words that essentially mean nothing, a woodman that states the obvious, and a dog that barks. Whatever, you've seen iffy writing before, and you continue.

But then you realize that you're incredibly slow. Annoyingly so. Most of the game is spent waiting for your character to slowly meander across the beautiful pixel landscape. You can only explore an area the first time through, but this game will keep sending you back and forth through it. So you deal with it.

This slowness carries through to your interactions with things. Everything needs to be clicked and held, or maybe rubbed for a while. Or strummed or touched just right, or poked a few times.

Which brings us to the puzzles. If you can call them that. You click and hold on a thing (for a while,) then you have to interact with... something. Sometimes that something glows, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes you need to slowly walk over to a mushroom and eat that first before you can see the thing you have to do something to. And once you figure out what you're interacting with, and how to interact with it, you have to divine what ORDER to interact with those things. I could find no rhyme, reason, or explanation to how this worked. It was pretty much just random clicking that eventually got me through.

'But this game is rated Mostly Positive in user reviews!' you say. And yes, it is, so you keep going, thinking that there's gotta be something incredibly redeeming about this game.

Perhaps this is so highly rated because it wallows in how artsy it is. Everything about this game is artsy. Yes, it's pretty. Yes, it sounds good. Yes, it's pretentious. But that doesn't make it good. Anyway, you think this, and continue on to...

The first boss. Now, combat up to this point has been pretty simple. There's been a wolf that you block attacks from, and it seems like you can't hit it, though it's never explained why not; and there was a statue or something that you blocked and then hit while it was stunned. That was actually pretty okay. But the boss? Oh no, it doesn't follow the few combat rules laid out up to this point.

So far, the player has been shown that you are capable of blocking god damn anything with your shield. So the boss betrays your trust with an unblockable attack. You fumble your way to finding the solution to this little problem and make it to the next step. Now the boss triggers an audio cue, at which point you tap the block button and dodge to the side. THIS IS NOT INDICATED OR USED UP TO THIS POINT. Until you dodge, you don't even know that dodging is a mechanic. This is terrible design.

Zelda gets blasted for overusing the new toy and throwing it away at the end of a dungeon. But do you know why they do that? The entire dungeon is spent training the player how to use said toy before offering a final test of the player's skill in the form of the boss fight. S:S&S throws this entire concept to the wind and throws random crap at you and laughs when you don't pick it up immediately.

I think the boss is supposed to be beaten through trial and error, but 'trial and error' and 'figue out the new mechanic on the spot' are not the same thing. And since everything takes so damn long (the boss's first attack is over a minute after you triger it, every time,) it's really hard to keep pushing yourself through this encounter.

I certainly didn't.

And that is why I do not recommend this game. Maybe get the soundtrack and poke a Let's Play or something, because it's really pretty and sounds great.

reviewText: When I first played the game, I thought the atmosphere and the art style was great. Although that was the only thing that this game really had to offer. In terms of gameplay, Sword & Sworcery had awkward point-and-click mechanics that would make walking from one side to another a chore especially since you have to walk through the same pathways over and over. The puzzles were too easy and combat was lackluster and unchallenging, making it annoying and pointless to fight that shadow guy everytime you have to walk through the same pathway a millionth time. The writing was also irritating as it tends to make unnecessary self-commentary everytime something happens that takes away any meaning to the story in a shallow attempt to be funny. And let's not forget that annoying voice acting of Logfella when he tries to make awkward conversations with you; it's unfunny and out of character (no attempt to sound like an old woodsman and instead sounds like an awkward teenager) which loses any immersion to the game. Overall I liked the style of the game but gameplay mechanics and story were not good. Not worth the 2 dollars I spent on this game.

reviewText:
First thing's first. See that title? Sword & Sworcery is an EP, not a game proper. It is music foremost and a storytelling experience second.

Despite what you may think and hear, this game is far from pretentious, and one of few examples where people will point to when they say that games can be art. Here is one so accutely self-aware that it nearly transcends it.

At its base, Sword & Sworcery is a wacky adventure tied onto a pretty nifty soundtrack. It is an experiment in modern storytelling and game design. A fruitful experiment, infusing music with puzzles and battles and decidedly not vice versa. The visuals, as you can already tell, are beyond stunning.

S&S is a game that tells its story almost in a sarcastic, tongue-in-cheek manner. At risk small of ruining the surprise, I will say this: it is exactly this silliness that both allows you to come even close to taking it seriously, and the cleverness that makes you appreciate it all the more.

If the plot were presented in a serious manner, few would take it seriously and it would just seem as pretentious and obfuscated as Braid. It is the humour and quirkiness of the title that makes the story penetrable at all. Despite the jests, the story is even more compelling if you take it as being honest.

Now here's the sad bits: this is not meant for the PC at all. Find yourself a touch screen copy of this game. It is not meant to be completed in one or two sittings. You are meant to pace yourself and take it in chunks, and you'll be more likely to finish the game that way.

Missing the ending is something you do not want to do. That is when everything sinks in.

reviewText: Music: The soundtrack. The soundtrack the soundtrack the soundtrack. Soundtrack? The. Soundtrack.\n\nSound Effects: I don't think I have ever commented on sound effects. I mean, voice acting, sure, but that to me is its own category. I also want to cater my chatter to the games themselves since oftentimes something stands out on its own and needs to be talked about. That said, the sound effects are crisp, elegant, real, magical. I think crisp is a delicious word; it makes me happy. Crisp. That was the first thing I thought of when I watched the Steam Release video. It carries throughout the game. Moments where there is little music are made vibrant by the sound effects. Not an oh I hear birds
date: how realistic" or "oh the people in the distant market
recommended: I can hear them!" vibrancy. It goes deeper into an almost trance inducing simplistic beauty. It dances in your mind. It dances with your mind.\n\nStory: Simple. At least to me it wasn't terribly deep
hoursPlayed: but I admit that I didn't spend an enormous amount of time in the game. The writing is superb though. I was pulled into the mystery of the game mostly becasue I didn't feel I had to be playing the game to be a part of it. The story became part of my own. The woeful errand is mine.\n\nGameplay (A): The controls and actual gameplay are brutally straightforward and it works. I felt good about accomplishing things but it was more of an "Ah-ha! Got it!" feeling than an "I did it! I can't believe it! YEEEEAAAAHHHH!" feeling. That said
voteText: the last part of the game gives you the latter feeling.\n\nGameplay (B): The way it incorporates into life would have been more engaging if I used twitter. Still

reviewText: Sort of a point-and-click game, largely based around music and sound design.  Sort of like Journey, in that it's as much an experience as a game.  But with very limited 8-16 bit graphics as art design that are very much in keeping with the minimalism.  Part of the game is figuring out how the interface works and how puzzles are supposed to be solved.  It's short, and I ran the range while playing it from thinking it was super simplistic to thinking the design aspect of it and the entire concept was transcendent brilliance, and then I was somewhat disappointed by a kind of abrupt ending that brought the game down a point or two for me.  Still, 8/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I got this game from a bundle, and at first it did not seem that much interesting to me. I can happily say that it was a bad mistake on my part, and that I recommend it.

Playing Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP has been a truly nice experience: as others said, the music, the art and the game itself have some peculiar quality that evoked in me a sense of wonder, and made me quite absorbed by the atmosphere of the game. I cannot forget how I sat at the campfire playing music and wondering how simple and beautiful it was.
Talking about cons, some may be disappointed by the game length (but I do not consider this bad, as it feels right for the game), or may have issues with the control system, but these do not not outweight the pros about the game at all. Talking about the price, I do not hide that the current one (5.99 €) may have deterred me from buying it. Still, I find it a rather reasonable price for the experience this game offers.

reviewText: This is perhaps the most INDIE indie game out there. While the visual art and music are technically decent, they just kinda seem like the same ♥♥♥♥ we've seen over the last couple years with no real flavor. Other than the sheer size of the enviroments, nothing really stands out. AThe majority of the time is spent walking around very slowly around big ♥♥♥ environments. Some would call this building atmosphere, but without engaging mechanics or story or REALLY good visuals and sound it just becomes a bore.  Occassionally you get combat, which is simple block->counterattack fair that is a disgrace to the legacy of Punch-Out. Then there are the puzzles" which boil down to find a couple hidden objects then click them in a vaguely rhythmic order. There's exactly one real puzzle that the achievements straight up tell you the answer to. The plot follows a bunch of characters that are never really developed on some quest we have no real stake in told through a narrator that sounds like some hipster who really likes Adventure Time. The big gimmick is the weird metaaspects of "The Archtype" telling you how to play the game and what you are supposed to be getting out of it
date: as well the ability to post ♥♥♥♥ you do to twitter and follow the in-game characters. This is just the sour prentious icing on the bland
recommended: mediocre cake. Maybe this ♥♥♥♥ was impressive on phones
hoursPlayed: but on the PC it just doesn't stand."

reviewText:
A 2D side-scroller of sorts, S&S:EP tells the story of a rather unremarkable character known only as the Scythian, who goes on a journey to capture three Trigon pieces and offer up the Megatome at the summit of a mountain.

Let me start by noting immediately that the production value is definitely up there. The visuals and especially the soundtrack are top-notch and definitely a major selling point of the game. The story is weaker and nothing spectacular, but definitely acceptable.

Where the game gets questionable is, well, the gameplay. It is not bad per se, but a lot of features in this game can be considered quite frustrating, from the mundane (tedious walking in between places) to the estoric (why do puzzles depend on real-life moon phases?). S&S:EP aims to be unique, and it seems that one will either find the gameplay brilliant and refreshing, or pretentious and merely annoying as hell.

For this reason, if at all possible, my recommendation: try before you buy - this is not a game for everyone, not even a majority. I hesitantly list this as a yes"

recommended: you can have a few pretty scenes and nice music for your money."

reviewText:
A game meant to be played for its music. The sound in this game is good and the music captures the atmosphere. There are a few quirky characters with some funny dialogue.

There are several issues with game. The graphics are bad (ie. 2D pixle style), however that might have been due to the art direction that was chosen. The gameplay is simple and bland as you just click with the mouse to move,attack and select stuff. The storyline isn't that memorable either. You don't get to go to different towns (ie you just switch between a mundane dreamworld and a forest) or get different weapons (ie. all you get is sword and shield).

If you like point and click games then this game is alright, else stay clear!

reviewText: Music: The soundtrack. The soundtrack the soundtrack the soundtrack. Soundtrack? The. Soundtrack.\n\nSound Effects: I don't think I have ever commented on sound effects. I mean, voice acting, sure, but that to me is its own category. I also want to cater my chatter to the games themselves since oftentimes something stands out on its own and needs to be talked about. That said, the sound effects are crisp, elegant, real, magical. I think crisp is a delicious word; it makes me happy. Crisp. That was the first thing I thought of when I watched the Steam Release video. It carries throughout the game. Moments where there is little music are made vibrant by the sound effects. Not an oh I hear birds
date: how realistic" or "oh the people in the distant market
recommended: I can hear them!" vibrancy. It goes deeper into an almost trance inducing simplistic beauty. It dances in your mind. It dances with your mind.\n\nStory: Simple. At least to me it wasn't terribly deep
hoursPlayed: but I admit that I didn't spend an enormous amount of time in the game. The writing is superb though. I was pulled into the mystery of the game mostly becasue I didn't feel I had to be playing the game to be a part of it. The story became part of my own. The woeful errand is mine.\n\nGameplay (A): The controls and actual gameplay are brutally straightforward and it works. I felt good about accomplishing things but it was more of an "Ah-ha! Got it!" feeling than an "I did it! I can't believe it! YEEEEAAAAHHHH!" feeling. That said

reviewText:
My rating: 5.5 / 10

Sword and Sworcery has some truly good qualities that are unfortunately negated by its inability to be anything more than a mediocre game.

Pros:
- Pleasing visual style. Very unique.
- Deep and ambient soundtrack.
- Interesting little secrets here and there.

Cons:
- Dull gameplay. A lot of the game spent watching your character walk around.
- Basic but lacking story with no real explanation.
- Frustrating controls, especially during combat.
- Pretentious tone that ruins the immersion and overall feel of the game.
- Useless Twitter integration being shoved down your throat.

As a work of visual and auditory art, S&S succeeds in being profound. However, as a game, it only succeeds in being a pretentious pile of hipster garbage.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If you're anything like me, you were probably instantly intrigued when you first saw screenshots of this. The appeal ends there. This game is just another pretty face, another cheap tart of no lasting worth. It is practically devoid of any interesting or meaningful gameplay, the puzzles boil down to clicking all over the screen and short-term memory, and the dialogue desperately tries to be charming and quirky, but ends up being patrionising and obnoxious. While the artstyle is for the most part lovely, it still boggles my mind wondering where the praise for this has come from. The music isn't even particularly good. This may be listed as a recommendation, dear friend, but this is very much a warning.

Buy it on sale, and play it as a change of pace from whatever survival horror game you've got going lately.  Oh .  .  . the music IS pretty good too.

reviewText:
I got this game from a bundle, and at first it did not seem that much interesting to me. I can happily say that it was a bad mistake on my part, and that I recommend it.

Playing Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP has been a truly nice experience: as others said, the music, the art and the game itself have some peculiar quality that evoked in me a sense of wonder, and made me quite absorbed by the atmosphere of the game. I cannot forget how I sat at the campfire playing music and wondering how simple and beautiful it was.
Talking about cons, some may be disappointed by the game length (but I do not consider this bad, as it feels right for the game), or may have issues with the control system, but these do not not outweight the pros about the game at all. Talking about the price, I do not hide that the current one (5.99 €) may have deterred me from buying it. Still, I find it a rather reasonable price for the experience this game offers.

reviewText:
This game is one of those rare creations that feels like a bright flash in the midnight sky.  Not everyone is going to see it, but those who do will remember it until they die.

The visuals make me think Zelda and feel Loom.  The music is some of the best this side of Hotline Miami and it has a perfect organic fit with the rest of the game. Though the story seems to take place in a dream world, references to real places and ancient people make it feel like it could have really happened. People who love language will love the writing.  I often found myself reading the lines out loud because they were so much fun to say.  I think the greatest success of the game is its ability to invite the player's imagination into the experience.

My only small criticism is that the original's touch controls don't always translate perfectly to the mouse, but I hardly cared because I was too busy having a great time.

reviewText: With the plethora of indie garbage floating around, there's very few titles that really stand out as being memorable. Sword & Sworcery EP is definitely one of those titles that stands out. It's a musical journey with epic gameplay, storytelling, sound effects, and music. I can't praise the sound effects and music enough--they make everything come together in spectacular fashion--it's gaming nirvana.\n\nGraphic-wise, the game isn't much to look at, but if you've ever played the original King's Quest, it's just an amazing throw-back to that era. Overall, Sword & Sworcery EP is a stunning adventure, both nostalgic and modern.

reviewText: The premise is a puzzle based point and click, but it uses some very cool imagery and scenery to form many of the puzzles in the game. There is also a real world/dream world dynamic, where actions in the dream world effect the story and puzzles of the real world. It's a very surreal game that really makes you want to keep exploring it; and while the setting and retro graphics seem simple on the surface, the wonder and mystery of the world is not something you will have encountered before. I can see this game not being for everyone, as at times it can be a little slow and the 'next step' can be a little vague and require lots of wandering to figure out. I see this as a normal part of an adventure game and wasn't put off by it, but would understand if anyone had issues with it. If you have this game in your library, pop it on some evening where you just want a relaxed game night :)

reviewText: The design of this game is unlike anything I've seen before. The interaction between puzzles and just getting around is well thought out and it keeps you on your toes. They took an interesting approach adding a feature to live tweet in the middle of the game, but what you're able to tweet can be quite entertaining. The visual effects are amazing differing from area to area and the overall disgust for rainbows is something to laugh at. Each character quickly builds their own unique personalities into the story which can cause you to care more about what they might have to say at each turning point. One can appreciate that breaks are recommended after you complete each act, giving you the opition to instantly turn the game off or continue right away. While the fighting system may grow dull, the story keeps you hooked in enough to bare through it. Lastly, the soundtrack is phenomenal. Being free to create your own sounds at certain points throughout the game, it helps to have well composed music that fits the mood in every scenario and is delightful to listen to on its own.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText: Wow... I owned this game for a long time before playing it. I had no idea what I was missing out on. Great retro adventure game, with an interesting story that isn't shoved down the players throat. The player is thrown into a world s/he knows nothing about, in a game where the mechanics are not explained by some boring tutorial or lame on-screen directions. Instead, the game cleverly introduces concept little by little, nudging the player to understand. Doing all of this, without being frustrating or annoying, rather keeping the player intrigued to know more.  Also great for casuals as it is divided up into sections that seem to take 30-45 minutes. GREAT GAME, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of the best games I have played this year. It's blend of lush, beautiful pixel art, engrossing sound effects and score, and intuitve gameplay sets the bar for indie games several pegs higher.

Although the gameplay mechanics are designed for touch-enabled devices, I had no issues using a mouse to click, drag, and strum my way though game. The combat system was probably easier on touch, but I only encountered a few mis-clicks in my five-and-a-half hour playthrough.

I believe it would be very easy for someone to beat this game for the first time in four hours, but I managed to get turned around a few times, especially in Session 3. The characters generally guide you along well enough to your next goal, though the hints can be quite cryptic at times. When I did finally find my way again, it was only then that I realized the true meaning.

At its core, the indiekid/hipster vibe of this game will either make or break the experience for you. The vocal tracks, few and far between, remind me of more of a spaced-out Bill and Ted than one would expect from a game, and both the developers and sound/music guy Jim Guthrie managed to have cameos. I found these traits endearing, the final polish on an already unblemished game. If you find yourself allergic to alliteration (or pretentiousness), then you might have a hard time with this one.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a unique game (if it can be called a game). It's more of an experience? The main focus is not the game itself but the pixel art and the clever use of sound and music. The music always matches the mood of the action giving you upbeat and epic tunes during battles and soft ambient tunes during exploration. In fact, battles were my favorite parts of the game (though there were few). They battles are simple patterns of attack and defense but they still prove to be fun and sometimes a bit intense.

While there are some definite good aspects of this game, there are other aspects that have me torn and make this game somewhat difficult to recommend. First of all, when playing this game, you have to remember that it was intended for mobile devices and tablets. I didn't understand that at first and was instantly frustrated with the controls. Touching and tapping has been replaced with mouse controls. It's still a bit confusing but you get used to it. My second gripe is that you as a player have very little idea of who your character is, what she is doing, and why (you understand more towards the end but for most of the game, you will be confused). It's important to check your surroundings, interact with characters, and listen to what they say (though they can be deliberately cryptic at times). This bring me to my next complaint... This game works fine, it looks good but there was something that kept bothering me and I couldn't quite figure it out until a couple of other users pointed it out in their own reviews. The game feels pretentious. Something about the overall presentation... The flashing of the game's title every now and then in-game, the flowery language of the archetype narrator, the fact that your character is known a The Scythian" while other characters get names like "Logfella"... It's difficult to place the blame on one aspect but something is not quite right about this game's overall atmosphere.

Overall
date: this is not a bad game. And maybe I'm wrong and this atmosphere was not the intention of the game's developers. So if you're into point-and-click
hoursPlayed: and music type things... Then give Sword & Sworcery a try and decide for yourself. It's a unique experience that you won't find elsewhere."

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is a simple and quirky mouse-driven adventure game with an excellent soundtrack and deceptively captivating art style.

There's really not much else to say when it comes to this game. This game does not overstay its welcome and does an excellent job of setting the player on a vague adventure through a forest where they must find magical triangles for no clearly defined purpose. This game's humor is extremely self-aware, and is often juxtaposed by the game's sense of epic art direction. Speaking of the art, it's hard to hide that this game uses a sprite based style that is actually more impressive than you might first think. Animations are extremely fluid, and you'll find yourself captivated by pixel art that looks fairly mediocre in stills yet springs to life in motion.

More important than anything else is this game's atmosphere and theme. This game has a wonderful soundtrack that plays many nature-inspired tunes while you walk around solving nature-inspired puzzles in your quest to find the magical Trigon. It's a difficult feeling to describe, which is why I have to recommend feeling it firsthand. There's something very earthy about the way this game presents itself.

However, if I had to find pick one gripe about this game it'd be the Moon Mood" system in Session III. Regardless of how you decide to manipulate this game to utilize it
date: a gameplay-based way and system manipulation-based way"
recommended: the process is tedious and puts an unnecessary damper on the game's overall pace. However
hoursPlayed: it is a minor gripe when the rest of the game is so captivating.\n\nOverall it's extremely easy to recommend this game. If you're looking for a relaxing puzzle-adventure game with an excellent soundtrack this is an easy must buy! Especially when it's on sale!"
voteText: August 19, 2015

reviewText: Sword & Sworcery is a unique take on an old adventure platform game.  Its visuals are a throwback to the old days of 8-bit graphics but powered by today's powerhouse graphics processors.  To describe this game is difficult.  But its charm lies within its musical melodies and its simple adventure puzzle.  Its only drawback would be its length, as it is possible to finish the game in one sitting.  However, one should slowly progress through the game to soak in all the visual and audio beauty.

reviewText: I had pretty high expectations for this game and it mostly delivered.  The gameplay itself is pretty basic: movement is done by double clicking a place on the screen and combat has only two buttons (attack or block).   Most of the odd controls are due to the game being an iOS port, but beyond the odd phrasing of the tutorial the controls are pretty decent.  The game gets better when it starts giving you puzzles: early on you unlock the power to sing" and can interact with the environment to progress.  Mostly this boils down to clicking on the screen like a maniac until you figure out the order of things to press but there are few times where the game actually surprises you beyond the cookie-cutter puzzles that are introduced at the start of the game.\n\nHowever
date: the story more than makes up for the decent gameplay.  The game presents you with a fairly original fantasy universe where most of the lore is told in the background.  Once you finish the first act
recommended: you gain access to a device that allows you to see what other characters think about the events going on; this gives more lore and occasionally hints about how to progress.  Our universe's lingo mixes in occasionally: words like "upload" find their way into the dialogue and help create a mix of fantasy and contemporary.  The game surprised me with its unique sense of humor as well; the game is narrated in first person and this often leads to humorous self-revelations.  The game is a visual treat with its stylized and elongated pixel characters and rich backgrounds.  Of course the music is also incredible: the game was made with the music in mind and it shows.\n\nThe game took me around 4.5 hours
hoursPlayed: which is decently long for a cheap indie game.  It doesn’t lend itself to be replayed
voteText: although there are a few easter eggs you may miss on your first run through.  The game splits itself into 4 parts; the third part notably takes a whole lunar month to complete (unless you are a cheater).  I suggest you follow the game’s recommendation to take a break between acts; it helps break the sometimes repetitive gameplay.  Overall
helpfulPercent: it’s worth the asking price and is for sure a buy if it goes on sale for $5 or less."

reviewText:
Bit of an experimental game, which comes through in some areas and not others.

The Bad:
Like most attempts to simplify games by going mouse heavy and keyboard light, movement in this game becomes a bit of a clunky nightmare.  In fact any attempt to make this a chill game goes out the window with the frustration of just trying to walk 4 feet.  Sometimes you click and walk, sometimes just a meaningless black circle floats there, making you ask the game What the hell do you want from me?  WALK!"

The descriptions of things
date: in an attempt to be hip
recommended:
come across as lazy and condescending.  A game with 4-bit graphics should put some actual effort into verbal descriptions.

The Good:
Unlike most games that talk about the soundtrack as part of their description
hoursPlayed: this game really does have an absolutely killer soundtrack.  Atmospheric as hell.  In fact the entire atmosphere of the game is pretty enjoyable.  The kind of low budget yet immersive game that is fun to check out
voteText: and that I'd like to see more of.\n\nAnd also

reviewText:
This game is one of those rare creations that feels like a bright flash in the midnight sky.  Not everyone is going to see it, but those who do will remember it until they die.

The visuals make me think Zelda and feel Loom.  The music is some of the best this side of Hotline Miami and it has a perfect organic fit with the rest of the game. Though the story seems to take place in a dream world, references to real places and ancient people make it feel like it could have really happened. People who love language will love the writing.  I often found myself reading the lines out loud because they were so much fun to say.  I think the greatest success of the game is its ability to invite the player's imagination into the experience.

My only small criticism is that the original's touch controls don't always translate perfectly to the mouse, but I hardly cared because I was too busy having a great time.

reviewText:
Time Played: 4 Hours
100% Achievements

Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP features Jim Guthrie in a Point and Click Adventure. In this type of genre, dialogue and an interesting appealing character usually drive the story forward. However, both of these were absent. There was no desire  whatsoever to empathize with the main character. Along with tedious puzzles, it proved to be a very frustrating experience. Definitely not worth $7.99 or whatever you paid for.

Jim Guthrie?

reviewText: The design of this game is unlike anything I've seen before. The interaction between puzzles and just getting around is well thought out and it keeps you on your toes. They took an interesting approach adding a feature to live tweet in the middle of the game, but what you're able to tweet can be quite entertaining. The visual effects are amazing differing from area to area and the overall disgust for rainbows is something to laugh at. Each character quickly builds their own unique personalities into the story which can cause you to care more about what they might have to say at each turning point. One can appreciate that breaks are recommended after you complete each act, giving you the opition to instantly turn the game off or continue right away. While the fighting system may grow dull, the story keeps you hooked in enough to bare through it. Lastly, the soundtrack is phenomenal. Being free to create your own sounds at certain points throughout the game, it helps to have well composed music that fits the mood in every scenario and is delightful to listen to on its own.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText:
Here's the deal: I liked this game. Yeah, it's a mobile game ported to PC and that does mean it isn't technically flawless. But man, I remember staying up in a room with no air conditioning in the middle of summer playing it and being like...two hours late for something because I wanted to finish this in one sitting.  I think I was meeting Mike for something. Mike, I'm sorry.

On the whole it's a really well made and fun adventure game that does a fantastic job at telling its story in a world that's filled to bursting with mysterious and enticing tone. The whole experience is truly evocative; a quest that will somehow lead you straight to peril, a la Shadow of the Colossus. The story itself is compelling and the game does a wonderful job of doing as much storytelling through the beautifully realized environments and haunting sound design as it does through actual text.

And here's the cool thing about that. Sword and Sworcery swings almost all of its weight in those departments to create an engrossing experience. Why do I care about the world? Because it's simultaneously beautiful and enticing, it beckons for you to explore it. How do I know it's not just goofy? Because the music and the design of each area inform you of the mood there, you can tell when you're supposed to chuckle and when you're supposed to be on edge. Why do you press on? Because it looks like a quest-y video game, what else would you do?

Where does it fall apart? That's why I want you to play it. Personally, I think the narrator breaking things up is a bit to cheeky for the tone of the game (at least as I remember it almost a year later). Yeah, some of the combat controls are a little wonky, yeah the movement can be a teeny bit frustrating. But really, I want you to play this. I want you to understand what good design is: bringing all aspects of the experience together to create something that you want to spend time with, characters you feel for even if you don't know them well, and provide you with a story that you remember vividly enough to tell your little nephew at a camping trip 6 months after finishing it. It'll provide you with that wide-eyed childlike joy of exploration and the bittersweet joy of completion.

If this does convince you to buy the game, message me after it's done. I want to talk about it. So bad.

reviewText: This is one of those games that I would classify more as an interactive fiction than a game; the story, art style, and music certainly make S:S&SEP worthwhile but the gameplay is lacking. The gameplay consists of annoying point-and-click controls, confusing puzzle mechanics (though the puzzles are solved easily) and a lack of replayablitity. It only took me 4.3 hours to complete the game and to get all of the achievements, so if you're looking for value I would wait until it's on sale. I would recomend this to those who are looking for an interesting (albiet short) story, but playing this game has not impacted me significantly.

reviewText:
I got this game from a bundle, and at first it did not seem that much interesting to me. I can happily say that it was a bad mistake on my part, and that I recommend it.

Playing Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP has been a truly nice experience: as others said, the music, the art and the game itself have some peculiar quality that evoked in me a sense of wonder, and made me quite absorbed by the atmosphere of the game. I cannot forget how I sat at the campfire playing music and wondering how simple and beautiful it was.
Talking about cons, some may be disappointed by the game length (but I do not consider this bad, as it feels right for the game), or may have issues with the control system, but these do not not outweight the pros about the game at all. Talking about the price, I do not hide that the current one (5.99 €) may have deterred me from buying it. Still, I find it a rather reasonable price for the experience this game offers.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of those unique gems that just plain works. The art direction is both bizarre and beautiful, and the soundtrack is one of the best I have ever heard in gaming. The story is so simple yet insanely deep, and the ending is one to think about for a long time. Although it is a short 4-hour campaign, it is very much a deeper game than the majority of AAA games on the market. Superbrothers is just plain brilliant.

But on the flip side, the controls are pretty bad on PC/Mac. Unfortunately, the game was original designed and released on iOS, and it suffers in transition. Moving the screen around, zooming in and zooming out, and combat are all much more complicated with the mouse than with touch screen.

But despite the bad controls, this is very much a worthy investment and one of the most unique and powerful indie games I have ever played. Definitely a recommend!

reviewText:
! 7/10

The one problem with this game is its designed for tablet or touch surface in particular. This can lead to an epic battle digressing to a show down with your mouse and the two button battle mode instead of the in-game enemy.
Outside of this issue the aesthetic balance between the game's graphics and sound is amazing. The sound pairs with the actions you preform in the game enviroment so readily that you experience a whole new dynamic to the gameplay rarely felt in games; where sound becomes as stirring an emotional influence as the visuals. Many of the scenes are so well crafted that the sound effects of enemies, or even your own actions, blend seamlessly into the music giving the impression of perfect symmetry between player and game as even your own decisions occur seemingly in perfectly harmony with the soundscape.
It has been a long time since a game enviroment has engrossed me to the extent that video games did in my early childhood taking me on epic adventures and journeys. Play Sword and Sworcery for the good laughs from the offbeat humor and the musical crescendo of nostalgia that is its classic story line.

reviewText:
EDIT: OK, so I recently finished the game and started it again (to collect some achievements) and I can now honestly say that S: S&S EP is probably one of the best single player games ever made! I could not recommend this any more! If you don't have it - buy it now and enjoy awesome gameplay, storyline and soundtrack!

Old post: I was hesitating whether to buy this, because I'm not quite into point-and-click adventures/quests. A friend of mine was telling me the game is awesome and that I need to play it. So I thought now that it's the deal of the day, it's a good idea to go buy it.

So I did. And wow! Just... WOW...

I immediately played the introduction and am astounded. I don't have much to say, except that everybody has to play that game! And I mean EVERYBODY!

Although I'm just in the beginning, I feel the story's gonna amaze me. The graphics are a true oldschool delight and the sounds/music... Oh, the music... You have to hear it so you can feel it!

So, yeah... I strongly recommend this miracle of a game to everybody.

reviewText: This is an amazing game with a great atmosphere. Its a point and click adventure game that features a female protagonist known as The Scythian. Like most Adventure games, you are required to click around to solve puzzles, explore amazing locales and unlock the secrets that lie within. Within what? Find out for for yourself.\n\nWhat I like about the game is the pixilated style that reminds me of PC games from the past like King's Quest, etc., etc. The characters in the game are fairly simple but pretty likeable. Their names pretty quirky and simple  like Logfella"
date: "Dogfella" or just plain "Girl". It the design of the game is so neat to look at that it feels like you can just stay here forever and just look at all the pixel art and how smooth it looks.\n\nTo accompany the pixel art is the music. My god the game boasts a mean soundtrack
recommended: composed by Indie Game: The Movie's own Jim Guthrie whose sound will make you want to "believe"
hoursPlayed: as they say in the trailers. I swear the music in the game is so fantastic that I went to their official website and bought a vinyl disc of their soundtrack. It's that great.\n\nThere are some flaws to the game though
voteText: one which regards to the length of the game. In truth the game could be about 3-5 hours long but the developers made the decision to  lengthen that out to what may take months instead. Without spoiling
helpfulPercent: I will say you will come back to the game each day to find out if it's the right time to progress the story. You might miss it if you wait too long and have to wait.\n\nI recommend this game to any fan of Point and Click Adventure fans. I believe its very worth it."

reviewText:
Spectacular game. Really deep. A bit weird to get in to (I didn't the first time around), perhaps due to the art style or the controls, but when you give it a chance the story becomes the primary motivation for completion. It makes you think a little; gives an interesting perspective of Dreams, Life, & Death.
The music is a perfect compliment.

On a lighter note, I do love how there's an achievement that unlocks if you're a cheater.. had to start a 2nd game just to cheat for it (but I made sure to unlock that one last). :P Cost wise, It's inexpensive, too! Came down to roughly $1/hr having taken my time. Not a lot of downsides!

Fairly short (100% + 14/14 Achievements in 7hrs), but overall I'm happy with it. Achievement wise, 2 of them are very difficult to achieve.

The ending? ... Oh, the ending. It made it all worth it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: In a sea of indie games ranging from bad to mediocre to amazing, some titles have really stood out to me. This is one of the games that left a lasting impression in the best of ways. This game does a great job of creating a stylistic experience that is always entertaining, despite being designed for touch devices and having a gameplay difficulty aimed at the most casual of audiences. The game excels mostly in its audio and visuals. The game looks fantasic. The stylized sprites look great and really look smooth in their animations, not to mention the beautiful environments that are augmented by some great lighting. The audio is even better. This game features a soundtrack that is beyond great. The music fits perfectly with each scene and transitions are seemless making the soundtrack is worth listening as a stand alone experience. Even the voice acting and dialog are great. The dialog is witty and the VA adds a little extra spice when it is rarely used.\n\nThis game is a great experience for the price and time.

reviewText: Wow... I owned this game for a long time before playing it. I had no idea what I was missing out on. Great retro adventure game, with an interesting story that isn't shoved down the players throat. The player is thrown into a world s/he knows nothing about, in a game where the mechanics are not explained by some boring tutorial or lame on-screen directions. Instead, the game cleverly introduces concept little by little, nudging the player to understand. Doing all of this, without being frustrating or annoying, rather keeping the player intrigued to know more.  Also great for casuals as it is divided up into sections that seem to take 30-45 minutes. GREAT GAME, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Superbrothers: Sword & Sworcery EP is one of the best games I have played this year. It's blend of lush, beautiful pixel art, engrossing sound effects and score, and intuitve gameplay sets the bar for indie games several pegs higher.

Although the gameplay mechanics are designed for touch-enabled devices, I had no issues using a mouse to click, drag, and strum my way though game. The combat system was probably easier on touch, but I only encountered a few mis-clicks in my five-and-a-half hour playthrough.

I believe it would be very easy for someone to beat this game for the first time in four hours, but I managed to get turned around a few times, especially in Session 3. The characters generally guide you along well enough to your next goal, though the hints can be quite cryptic at times. When I did finally find my way again, it was only then that I realized the true meaning.

At its core, the indiekid/hipster vibe of this game will either make or break the experience for you. The vocal tracks, few and far between, remind me of more of a spaced-out Bill and Ted than one would expect from a game, and both the developers and sound/music guy Jim Guthrie managed to have cameos. I found these traits endearing, the final polish on an already unblemished game. If you find yourself allergic to alliteration (or pretentiousness), then you might have a hard time with this one.

reviewText: A good port of a very creative game, but some of the design choices that make perfect sense for iPad/iPhone feel a little awkward on PC, such as the prodding to post on a social media site after every level. Because the game was so clearly based around a touch interface, using a mouse to interact actually feels a little clumsy. I ultimately had fun with this version, but honestly, if you have a tablet or phone that can run it, I would say get that version instead.

reviewText: This is one of those games that I would classify more as an interactive fiction than a game; the story, art style, and music certainly make S:S&SEP worthwhile but the gameplay is lacking. The gameplay consists of annoying point-and-click controls, confusing puzzle mechanics (though the puzzles are solved easily) and a lack of replayablitity. It only took me 4.3 hours to complete the game and to get all of the achievements, so if you're looking for value I would wait until it's on sale. I would recomend this to those who are looking for an interesting (albiet short) story, but playing this game has not impacted me significantly.

reviewText:
This game.

THIS GAME.

This game is very very good.

(I don't have a sense to whether these are minor or major spoilers, but it think of it as minor spoilers.)

This game takes gives you the experience of traversing a small land.
A land you never thought you'd see when you loaded up this game.
A land not so different from your own.
A land full of lush forest, soothing sounds, and a journey you'll remember to the ends of your days.
...and in the end, you'll be left heartbroken. miserable. This game puts your mind on an emotional rollercoaster. What you think is the core goal. That thing, that you keep working towards and working towards is always getting closer, but do you really want to continue?

The answer is yes. Obviously.

But then you watch, as your friend, this character that you grow attached to, this character that charmed you over with her third-person, cynical style. This Scythian girl who wants only to rid herself of this new horror that torments her, and seal away that which she can't deal with...

You watch as she slowly fades.

This girl who wants the same goal as you. Watch as you lead her through fight after fight, leading her closer to your mutual goal. And she fades. Her health is but a secondary note as you fight to your ultimate goal.

But is it really worth it? Is it really worth sacrificing the life of this girl to seal what could be this eternal monster that haunts her forever? Do you wan't to watch her through every moment of her everlasting agony, as she's injured, diseased, and physically destroyed from your escapades to rid her of her problem?

Well, I guess that's really your decision. Isn't it?

reviewText: The most accessible adventure game I've ever played.  If you're new to the genre, don't be afraid to try this one out -- it's got a great balance of action, storytelling, and puzzle-solving.  It's also beautiful and has some of the best music I've heard in a game in a long time.  This one's a real audio-visual treat with a neat little game packed inside.  I pretty much got an iPod just so I could play it and I don't regret that one bit.  It's just that good.

reviewText: Quirky, fun writing supported by a solid, vibrant universe and satisfying gameplay elements. Sword and Sworcery is given life by the sound design and music by Jim Guthrie, but the pixel graphics are a feast of the eyes, as is the universe in all. Mythical, adventurous and relaxing.\n\nI recommend you buy this whenever you can and let the game guide you for a few sessions of neat exploration. Seek out every little bit of detail this game's got in it!

reviewText: A very interesting game with no issue breaking the fourth wall with it's prodding to interact with Twitter. It's a point and click adventure game with a stellar soundtrack and a clean visual style. The dialogue is hilariously offbeat with a lot of satire taking shots at gaming cliches. It's packed with riddles that do a good job of being solvable, while not obvious, and has a fun way of providing hints and help throughout the game. It has a fairly short run time, so if you're concerned with getting your money's worth this game may not be for you. The experience was definitely new, and was refreshing to play through.

reviewText: This relatively short game is a deep collaborative hit. The game is largely centered on the audiovisual style, with pixelated graphics and immersed musical puzzles--mostly inspired by the Legend of Zelda series. It is a point and click adventure where you help the Scythian complete her woeful errand. The Archetype guides the player through the story providing hints and asks to stop playing in-between acts to digest what happened in the recently completed act. A few tasks may require time, thinking and patience to complete, but it is an adventure that no one should miss. The game does come with Jim Guthrie's extraordinary soundtrack.
